sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
The genus Clathria Schmidt, 1862
is the richest genus of the family Microcionidae , but only 20 species have been recorded from Brazil until now. Clathria ( Axosuberites ) Topsent, 1893 is characterized by having digitate, whip-like, arborescent and flabellate growth forms, lacking echinating spicules, well differentiated axial and extra-axial skeleton, styles and/or subtylostyles as principal spicules, and microscleres palmate isochelae and toxas. The subgenus contains 19 valid species, with worldwide distribution predominantly in shallow waters. Six species occur in the Atlantic Ocean and two of them are recorded from the Western Atlantic in South America: Clathria ( Axosuberites ) riosaeVan Soest, 2017 , and Clathria ( Axosuberites ) marplatensis ( Cuartas, 1992 )
. Specimens analyzed in this study were collected in 2015 at Mamanguape estuary, Paraíba State , and in 2017 at Tutóia beach, Maranhão State . Here we described two new species of Clathria ( Axosuberites )
for the first time in Brazilian waters: Clathria ( Axosuberites ) aurantia n. sp. and Clathria ( Axosuberites ) hillenburgi n. sp.
Key words: marine sponges, Microcionidae , Western Atlantic, taxonomy

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Microcionidae is characterized by having three skeletal regions defined by the presence of different forms of structural styles: choanosomal (axial) skeleton (spicules enclosed within spongin fibres and spined monactinal spicules typically echinating fibres), subectosomal (extra-axial or extra-fibre) skeleton and ectosomal skeleton; one or more skeletal regions may be lost or modified ( Hooper 2002 ). Two genera and two subgenera of this family are characterized by lacking the echinating spicules in their skeleton composition ( ArtemisinaVosmaer, 1885 , OphlitaspongiaBowerbank, 1866 , Clathria ( Axosuberites ) Topsent, 1893 and Clathria ( Isociella ) Hallman, 1920
), and in other genera, such as AnthoGray, 1867 , echinating spicules may be present ( Antho ( Acarnia ) Gray, 1867 ) or absent ( Antho ( Antho ) Gray, 1867 and Antho ( Isopenectya ) Hallmann, 1920 ).

The genus Clathria Schmidt, 1862
is the richest genus within Microcionidae and consists of nine subgenera and 388 valid species, six of these remain unassigned to a subgenus (
Van Soest et al ., 2019
). In Brazil , eighteen species and four subgenera of Clathria are recorded ( Muricy, 2019 ): Clathria ( Clathria ) calypsoBoury-Esnault, 1973 ; C .
( C .) nicoleaeBarros, Santos & Pinheiro, 2013 , C . ( Microciona ) achelataSandes & Pinheiro, 2016 , C .
( M .) calla (De Laubenfels, 1934)
, C .

( M .) echinata ( Alcolado, 1984 )
, C . ( M .) larae Cavalcanti, Santos & Pinheiro, 2018, C . ( M .) moraesi Cavalcanti, Santos & Pinheiro, 2018, C . ( M .) nisiae Cavalcanti, Santos & Pinheiro, 2018, C .
( M .) trairaeSantos & Pinheiro, 2014 ; C . ( Thalysias ) basiarenacea ( Boury-Esnault, 1973 )
; C .

, C .
( T .) repensGalindo, Hooper and Pinheiro, 2014 ; C .
( T .) venosa ( Alcolado, 1984 )

( M .) campecheae and C .
( T .) minuta co-occur in the Southeastern region. Prior to this study no Clathria ( Axosuberites )
species were known from Brazil .

Clathria ( Axosuberites )
is recognized by having skeleton compressed and well differentiated from plumose(- reticulate) extra-axial skeleton; echinating spicules absent; ectosomal skeleton with special category of (smaller) auxiliary style forming surface brushes ( Hooper 2002 ). Nineteen described species comprise the subgenus, two of which are known for South America coast: Clathria ( Axosuberites ) riosaeVan Soest, 2017 (from Suriname ) and Clathria ( Axosuberites ) marplatensis ( Cuartas, 1992 )
(from Mar del Plata, Argentina ). However, neither of these occur in Brazil . Herein, we provide a description of two new species of Clathria ( Axosuberites )
from northeastern Brazil , being the first records for the subgenus from the Brazilian coast.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p:
Specimens were collected by free diving at Paraíba State , municipality of Rio Tinto (Mamanguape estuary) ( 06°46’43.46’’S34°55’55.61’’W ) in 2015, and dragged by fishing net in Tutóia beach ( 02º45’13.000”S , 42º17’16.977”W ), Tutóia Municipality, Maranhão State in 2017 (
). All specimens were preserved in 80% ethanol and are deposited in the Porifera Collection at Universidade Federal de Pernambuco (UFPEPOR). Dissociated spicules and skeletal sections were prepared following
Hajdu et al . (2011)
.

FIGURE 1. Map showing the type localities of the species described in this study (created in QGIS software) (MA—Maranhão State; PB—Paraíba State). Black dot: Clathria ( Axosuberites ) aurantia sp. nov. ; Black triangle: Clathria ( Axosuberites ) hillenburgi sp. nov.

Measurements are given in micrometers (μm), arranged as minimum– mean –maximum. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) preparations and eletromicrographs were undertaken at CETENE ( Centro de Tecnologias Estratégicas do Nordeste) and Fundação Oswaldo Cruz (Fiocruz)— Pernambuco / Centro de Pesquisas Aggeu Magalhães (CPqAM) and at Centro de Pesquisa Gonçalo Moniz, Fundação Oswaldo Cruz (FIOCRUZ-BA). Images of specimens, sections (Leica DM 500 microscope) and SEM (Jeol JSM-5600LV) preparations were obtained digitally. Taxonomic classification followed the World Porifera Database (
Van Soest et al . 2019
) available for Clathria ( Axosuberites )
species.

tp:treatment-sec.p: Diagnosis. Digitate, whip-like, arborescent and flabellate growth forms; with well differentiated axial and extraaxial skeletal architecture, reminiscent of Raspailiidae ; axial skeleton markedly compressed, reticulate; extra-axial skeleton radial, plumose or plumo-reticulate composed of large subectosomal auxiliary styles-subtylostyles; specialised ectosomal skeleton present composed of smaller auxiliary spicules; echinating megascleres absent although principal spicules may protrude through fibres at acute angles; microscleres absent or may include palmate isochelae and toxas ( Hooper 2002 ).
Type locality: Brazil , Maranhão State , Tutóia Municipality, Tutóia beach, Brazil .

Type specimen:Holotype :
UFPEPOR 2351, Tutóia beach ( 02º45’13.000” S , 42º17’16.977” W ), Tutóia Municipality , Maranhão State , Brazil , coll. B. Annunziata , R . A. Silva , L. H. O. Souza , 24 July 2017 .

Distribution and ecology. The specimen was found in Tutóia Channel, about 9.5 km from the shore and was collected dragged by fishing nets, in Tutóia beach, Tutóia municipality, Maranhão State , Brazil .
Etymology. From Latin “ aurantius ” referring to its vivid orange color in life.

Remarks.Clathria ( Axosuberites ) aurantia n . sp .
as well as C. ( A .) papillataVan Soest, Beglinger & De Voogd, 2013 , and C. ( A .) riosaeVan Soest, 2017 differ from other C. ( Axosuberites ) species by the absence of toxas. However, the new species has smooth styles and one category of subtylostyles versus microspined styles in C. ( A .) papillata and two size categories of subtylostyles in C. ( A .) riosae (see Table 1 ). The main difference between C . ( Axosuberites ) aurantia n . sp .
and C. ( A .) pachyaxia ( Lévi, 1960 )
and C. ( A .) georgiaensisHooper, 1996 is the presence of toxas. In addition, there are some differences in the categories of their spicule arrangements and geographic distributions making specificity unlikely (see Table 1 ). Species of Axosuberites that have more than two categories of megascleres are: C. ( A. ) benguelaensisSamaai & Gibbons, 2005 , Clathria
( A .) canaliculata ( Whitelegge, 1906 )
, C. ( A. ) cylindrica ( Ridley & Dendy, 1886 )
, C. ( A .) flabellata (Topsent, 1916)
, C. ( A .) nidificata ( Kirkpatrick, 1907 )
, C .
( A .) patula ( Hooper, 1996 )
, and C .
( A .) thetidis ( Hallmann, 1920 )
. Species with much larger isochelae and stout styles are C .
( A .) fromontaeHooper, 1996 , C .
( A .) macrotoxa ( Bergquist & Fromont, 1988 )
, C. ( A .) marplatensis ( Cuartas, 1992 )
and C .
( A .) multitoxaformis ( Bergquist & Fromont, 1988 )
. Furthermore, two species show larger megascleres when compared to Clathria ( Axosuberites ) aurantia n . sp .
: Clathria
( A .) ramea ( Koltun, 1964 )
and C. ( A .) rositaGoodwin, Brewin & Brickle, 2012 .

Distribution and ecology. Known only from the type locality: Caracabu River/Estuary (Rio Tinto Municipality, Paraíba State , Brazil ), intertidal. Found in a mangrove area on roots of Rhizophora sp.
Etymology. The specific name is in honor to Stephen M. Hillenburg, marine biologist and creator of the cartoon character ‘SpongeBob SquarePants’.

Remarks.Clathria ( Axosuberites ) hillenburgi n. sp. is characterized by a spicule arrangement with (subtylo-)styles I and II, auxiliary subtylostyles, toxa and palmate isochelae. The new species resembles to Clathria
( A .) flabellata (Topsent, 1916)
and Clathria
( A .) georgiaensisHooper, 1996 (from the Antarctic Peninsula) by having two categories of styles and/or subtylostyles, toxas and palmate isochelae. However, Clathria ( A .) hillenburgi n. sp. is distinguished from Clathria
( A .) flabellata and Clathria
( A .) georgiaensis due having shorter styles and toxas (see Table 1 ). Differences in megascleres categories among the new species and Clathria
( A .) benguelaensisSamaai & Gibbons, 2005 , Clathria
( A .) nidificata ( Kirkpatrick, 1907 )
include the number of megascleres categories (two in the new species and four in the others). Clathria ( Axosuberites ) hillenburgi n. sp. distinguished from Clathria
( A .) marplatensis ( Cuartas, 1992 )
, Clathria
( A .) pachyaxia ( Lévi, 1960 )
, Clathria
( A .) papillataVan Soest, Beglinger & De Voogd, 2013 , Clathria
( A .) ramea ( Koltun, 1964 )
, and Clathria
( A .) rositaGoodwin, Brewin & Brickle, 2012 by having two categories of styles and one of subtylostyle versus two categories of styles in the others. The new species differs from C. ( A .) aurantia n. sp. , C. ( A .) riosaeVan Soest, 2017 and C. ( A .) papillataVan Soest, Beglinger & De Voogd, 2013 by the absence of toxas. Clathria
( A .) canaliculata and C. ( A. ) cylindrica have two categories of palmate isochelae, while the new species has only one category. Similarly, C. ( A. ) fromontae , C. ( A. ) macrotoxa , C. ( A. ) multitoxaformis and C. ( A. ) thetidis have two size categories of toxas, while C. ( Axosuberites ) hillenburgi n. sp. has only one category. Finally, the new species is distinguished from Clathria ( A. ) patula ( Hooper, 1996 )
by having three categories of styles.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In Clathria , two subgenera ( Axosuberites and Isociella ) lacking echinating acanthostyles. Two other genera of Microcionidae also lack echinating acanthostyles: Artemisina and Ophlitaspongia . In one genus ( Antho ) echinating spicules may be present ( Antho ( Acarnia )) or absent ( Antho ( Antho) and Antho ( Isopenectya )) ( Hooper 2002 ). The presence of echinating megascleres in Microcionidae can indicate the retention of an ancestral character ( Hooper 1991 ), but only through molecular analysis this condition can be confirmed.

The largest number of species placed in this genus may indicate that some species of other Microcionidae genera are misassigned as Clathria . The species Clathria ( Axosuberites ) nidificata and Clathria ( Axosuberites ) flabellata were originally described as Ophlitaspongia . These species were transferred to Clathria ( Axosuberites )
due having different morphologies than seen in Ophlitaspongia , including an erect and fan-shaped form with ramifications in C . ( Axosuberites ) flabellata , and massive and globular form in C . ( Axosuberites ) nidificata ( Hooper, 1996 )
. Clathria ( Axosuberites )
and Ophlitaspongia share the presence of subtylostyles, toxas and palmate isochelae, and absence of echinating megascleres. However, species in Ophlitaspongia have encrusting growth form and isodictyal reticulate spongin fibre skeleton arising from a hymedesmioid basal fibre skeleton ( Hooper 2002 ). There are other encrusting Clathria (mainly Clathria ( Microciona )
and Clathria ( Thalysias )) with absence of acanthostyles and similar spicule complement that should be revised.

With the description of C .
( A .) aurantia sp. nov. and C .
( A .) hillenburgi sp. nov .
, the Brazilian diversity of Clathria is now increased to twenty species and five subgenera of Clathria .
